name: TsComment
rawText:
/**
 * comments are basically one-or-multi-line human content inside of typescript files, so it's a very important to do something useful with them.
 *
 * special line prefixes:
 * - TODO:
 * - DISCUSSION:
 * - IDEA:
 * - LATER:
 * - NB:
 *
 * The convention should be that single-line comments should start with that. This then becomes the type of the comment.
 * You can also put multiple prefixes at the start.
 *
 * Example:
 *
 * `// TODO: NB: this is a todo but its also important`
 *
 * Multiline comments can also have one or multiple types in their text, but they should not be split into multiple comments as the context could be needed some times.
 *
 *
 *
 * There are also some other things comments can say about statements, but these should be inside the frontmatter, and are much more flexible.
 * - classified[0-10] indicating level of classification. This way I can share subsets of the codebase, maybe...
 * - privacy
 * - ...?
 *
 * NB: with the current setup we can also parse `.md` files as being a TsComment, keep it that way!
 *
 * NB: comments are part of the code, so they should always be in English!
 */

export interface TsComment extends IndexId {
  /**
   * the content of the comment in markdown, without frontmatter
   */
  comment: Markdown;
  /**
   * parameters destructured from the frontmatter of the parsed markdown (if comment is not a oneliner, otherwise it'll be empty)
   */
  parameters: FrontMatter;
  /**
   * These are the type indicators that were found in this single or multiline comment. Can be multiple.
   */
  types: CommentType[];

  /**
   * first line of the comment
   */
  firstLine: number;
  /**
   * last line of the comment
   */
  lastLine: number;
  /**
   * statement name the comment belongs to
   */
  statementName?: string;
  /**
   * raw statement text the comment belongs to
   */
  rawStatement?: string;
}
description:
comments are basically one-or-multi-line human content inside of typescript files, so it's a very important to do something useful with them.

special line prefixes:
- TODO:
- DISCUSSION:
- IDEA:
- LATER:
- NB:

The convention should be that single-line comments should start with that. This then becomes the type of the comment.
You can also put multiple prefixes at the start.

Example:

`// TODO: NB: this is a todo but its also important`

Multiline comments can also have one or multiple types in their text, but they should not be split into multiple comments as the context could be needed some times.



There are also some other things comments can say about statements, but these should be inside the frontmatter, and are much more flexible.
- classified[0-10] indicating level of classification. This way I can share subsets of the codebase, maybe...
- privacy
- ...?

NB: with the current setup we can also parse `.md` files as being a TsComment, keep it that way!

NB: comments are part of the code, so they should always be in English!

relativeOperationBasePathFromProjectRoot.description:
relative file path from the project-root to the operation (DOES include operation folder)

e.g. /tools/cognition/typescript/index-typescript

relativeFilePathFromSrc.description:
relative file path from the operation src

e.g. general.ts

srcFileId.description:
file id (same as relativeFilePathFromSrc but without extension)

e.g. "general"

operationFolderName.description: operation folder name (by convention, must be identical to operationName, but it could have some mistakes)

relativePathFromProjectRoot.description: relative file or folder path from the project root

comment.description: the content of the comment in markdown, without frontmatter

parameters.description: parameters destructured from the frontmatter of the parsed markdown (if comment is not a oneliner, otherwise it'll be empty)

types.description: These are the type indicators that were found in this single or multiline comment. Can be multiple.

statementName.description: statement name the comment belongs to

rawStatement.description: raw statement text the comment belongs to

schema.description:
relative file path from the project-root to the operation (DOES include operation folder)

e.g. /tools/cognition/typescript/index-typescript

relative file path from the operation src

e.g. general.ts

file id (same as relativeFilePathFromSrc but without extension)

e.g. "general"
operation package.json name
operation folder name (by convention, must be identical to operationName, but it could have some mistakes)
relative file or folder path from the project root
unique id of the model
name (identifier) of the model
kebab-case variant of the name
a string that is known to contain markdown.

first line of the comment

name: PathParse
description:
object to represent a folder or file path in different ways

NB: doesn't include the absolute path so the indexes can be exported easily witout creating incorrect paths
